Let us own the truth: what earth has produced as a cure for our ills, we have made into a deadly poison3 why, do we not also put her indispensable gift of iron to a similar use? Nor yet should we have any right to complain even if she had engendered poison to serve the purpose of crime. In fact in regard to one of nature's elements we have no grati- tude. For what luxuries and for what outrageous uses does she not sub'serve mankind? She is flung into the sea, or dug away to allow us to let in the channels. Water, iron, wood, sire, stone, growing crops, are employed to torture her at all hours‚ and much more to make her minister to our luxuries than our sustenance. Yet in order to make the sufferings inflicted on her surface and mere outer skin seem endurable, we probe her entrails, digging into her veins of gold and silver and mines of copper and lead3 we actually drive shafts down into the depth to search for gems and certain tiny stones; we drag out her entrails, we seek a jewel merely to be worn upon a finger!
